docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You reported (news article, Aug. 17) that New York City shut an unlicensed medical clinic serving Chinese immigrants, most of whom lacked health insurance. And an Aug. 19 news article described the survivors of the West Nile virus, including a Polish immigrant in Westchester County who is eligible only for emergency Medicaid, which covered her hospitalization but not rehabilitation services. These are the faces behind the changes in federal law that effectively deny Medicaid and State Child Health Insurance to most immigrants who entered the country after August 1996. Last year, 46 percent of immigrants in New York City did not have health insurance.
docs.abstract: Deborah Bachrach letter, commenting on August 17 and 19 articles, urges New York City to step into void created by federal government by providing help for growing number of immigrants without health insurance
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    You reported (news article, Aug. 17) that New York City shut an unlicensed medical clinic serving Chinese immigrants, most of whom lacked health insurance. And an Aug. 19 news article described the survivors of the West Nile virus,...

docs.lead_paragraph: They used their best Yiddish, not just the Jew but the Southern Baptist as well. The band, a brassy if somewhat anemic quintet (you were expecting the Rolling Stones?), played a medley that ran from ''Rocky Top'' to ''Happy Days Are Here Again'' to ''Hava Nagila.'' And one adoring voter, a lady with silver hair and red lipstick, told America's first Jewish vice-presidential nominee that kissing his hand was ''like kissing the Torah.'' Vice President Al Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, campaigned in southeast Florida for the first time today, setting off a frenzy at a largely Jewish community center and asserting that they would compete aggressively in this critical state.

headline.main: Gore and Company Making a Serious Play for Florida

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and Sen Joseph I Lieberman campaign together in southeast Florida, setting off a frenzy at a largely Jewish community center in Tamarac and asserting that they will compete aggressively in this critical state; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: PAPER PRIMARY PROTEST The City Board of Elections refused yesterday to reprint ballots for the Sept. 12 primary that now omit Green Party candidates, and will force party voters to choose their nominees on paper ballots. Green Party candidates will be on voting machine ballots everywhere else in the state. Craig Seeman, the party's state election coordinator, said that it would sue the city in federal court and that the board's claim that there is no room on ballots for the Green Party candidates was unacceptable. The Senate candidates include Al Lewis, above, who played Grandpa on ''The Munsters''; Mark Dunau, a farmer from Hancock, N.Y.; and Ron Dugger of Manhattan, a former newspaper publisher. (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: For Vice President Al Gore these days, there is no devil in the details. As he finished his four-day riverboat tour of the Mississippi River with a floating seminar on tax policy -- a significant departure from the crap games that once prevailed on these waters -- Mr. Gore tried to convey once again that his political message is built on a foundation of substance.

headline.main: For Gore, Life on Mississippi Is Full of Details

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and running mate Sen Joseph I Lieberman end four-day riverboat tour of Mississippi River in Hannibal, Mo, Mark Twain's boyhood home; Gore again moves to convey that his political message is built on foundation of substance; portrays himself as candidate of specifics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lena Cymbrowitz, a first-term state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 43. Her family said she had been ill for a long time, but gave no details.
docs.abstract: Lena Cymbrowitz, first-term state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, dies at age 43 (S)
docs.snippet: Lena Cymbrowitz, a first-term state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 43.    Her family said she had been ill for a long time, but gave no details.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cochlear implants have been used for almost a decade to help thousands of profoundly deaf children, but some two-thirds of insurance companies are often unwilling to pay, citing a lack of evidence that the devices are cost-effective. A new study, however, reports that over the course of a deaf person's life, the implants can save more than $50,000 in costs associated with the disability. It also found that the devices, used in children who are not helped by conventional hearing aids, have made a difference in the lives of the children using them.

headline.main: Aid for Deaf as Possible Cost-Saver, Too

docs.abstract: Study finds that cochlear implants, which have helped thousands of profoundly deaf children, can save more than $50,000 in costs associated with disability; findings counter refusal of many insurance companies to pay for procedure (S)
